questiontext.text:
Parametric form of a circle

We have seen in the previous example that we can parameterise a circle by using the trigonometric functions \(\sin \theta\) and \(\cos \theta\). This section will focus on using parametric representations of circles and identifying when a set of parametric equations gives us a circle. Let us begin by considering the following example.

Example

Find a parametric representation \(x = f(t), y = g(t)\) of the circle of radius \(9\) and centre \((-8,-8)\).

Solution

In this case, we know that the \(x\) coordinate will be a function of \(\cos t\) and the \(y\)-coordinate will be a function of \(\sin t\). Recall that we can write the Cartesian equation of this circle is given in centre-radius form as \[ (x+8)^2 + (y+8)^2 = 9^2. \] Then, notice that the functions \(f(t) = 9 \cos t -8\) and \(g(t) = 9 \sin t - 8\) satisfy: \[ \begin{align*} (f(t) - (-8))^2 + (g(t) - (-8))^2 &= (9 \cos t)^2 + (9 \sin t)^2 \\ &= 9^2 \cos^2 t + 9^2 \sin^2 t \\ &= 9^2 (\cos^2 t + \sin^2 t) \\ &= 9^2. \end{align*} \] Therefore a parametric representation of the circle is given by \(x = 9 \cos t - 8\), \(y = 9 \sin t -8\).


In general for a circle with centre-radius form \((x-a)^2 + (y-b)^2 = r^2\) the parametric form of the circle is given by \[ x = r \cos t + a \qquad \mbox{ and } \qquad y = r \sin t + b. \]
